messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 57 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Computing Hamiltonian Paths with Partial Order Restrictions

Paper Abstract: Abstract When solving the Hamiltonian path problem it seems natural to be given additional precedence constraints for the order in which the vertices are visited. For example one could decide whether a Hamiltonian path exists for a fixed starting point, or that some vertices are visited before another vertex. We consider the problem of finding a Hamiltonian path that observes all precedence constraints given in a partial order on the vertex set. We show that this problem is ùñ≠ùñØùñ≠ùñØ\mathsf{NP}-complete even if restricted to complete bipartite graphs and posets of height 2. In contrast, for posets of width kùëòk there is an ùí™‚Äã(k2‚Äãnk)ùí™superscriptùëò2superscriptùëõùëò\mathcal{O}(k^{2}n^{k}) algorithm for arbitrary graphs with nùëõn vertices. We show that it is unlikely that the running time of this algorithm can be improved significantly, i.e., there is no f‚Äã(k)‚Äãno‚Äã(k)ùëìùëòsuperscriptùëõùëúùëòf(k)n^{o(k)} time algorithm under the assumption of the Exponential Time Hypothesis. Furthermore, for the class of outerplanar graphs, we give an ùí™‚Äã(n2)ùí™superscriptùëõ2\mathcal{O}(n^{2}) algorithm for arbitrary posets.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 57 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 57"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The travelling salesman problem with precedence constraints",
        "A 5353\\frac{5}{3}-approximation algorithm for the clustered traveling salesman tour and path problems",
        "Easy problems for tree-decomposable graphs",
        "A cutting plane approach to the sequential ordering problem (with applications to job scheduling in manufacturing)",
        "A linear-time algorithm for the kùëòk-fixed-endpoint path cover problem on cographs",
        "The 1-fixed-endpoint path cover problem is polynomial on interval graphs",
        "A polynomial solution to the kùëòk-fixed-endpoint path cover problem on proper interval graphs",
        "The kùëòk-fixed-endpoint path partition problem",
        "On the end-vertex problem of graph searches",
        "Certifying fully dynamic algorithms for recognition and hamiltonicity of threshold and chain graphs",
        "Exact and heuristic procedures for the traveling salesman problem with precedence constraints, based on dynamic programming",
        "Hamiltonian paths and cycles in planar graphs",
        "A partial k-arboretum of graphs with bounded treewidth",
        "Influence of the tie-break rule on the end-vertex problem",
        "Worst-case analysis of a new heuristic for the travelling salesman problem",
        "Minimizing setups in ordered sets of fixed width",
        "LDFS-based certifying algorithm for the minimum path cover problem on cocomparability graphs",
        "On end-vertices of lexicographic breadth first searches",
        "A unified view of graph searching",
        "The monadic second-order logic of graphs. I: Recognizable sets of finite graphs",
        "Parameterized algorithms",
        "Graph theory, volume 173 of GTM",
        "A decomposition theorem for partially ordered sets",
        "Postman tour on a graph with precedence relation on arcs",
        "An inexact algorithm for the sequential ordering problem",
        "On the implementation of an algorithm for improving a solution to the sequential ordering problem",
        "On the parameterized complexity of multiple-interval graph problems",
        "Recognition algorithms for orders of small width and graphs of small dilworth number",
        "Obtaining a triangular matrix by independent row-column permutations",
        "Extendability of cyclic orders",
        "Cyclic ordering is NP-complete",
        "Well-solved special cases",
        "Algorithm 447: Efficient algorithms for graph manipulation",
        "An efficient parallel strategy for the two-fixed-endpoint hamiltonian path problem on distance-hereditary graphs",
        "A set of independent postulates for cyclic order",
        "Sets of completely independent postulates for cyclic order",
        "Which problems have strongly exponential complexity?",
        "Hamilton paths in grid graphs",
        "Finding Hamiltonian circuits in interval graphs",
        "Linear time LexDFS on cocomparability graphs",
        "Graphs where search methods are indistinguishable",
        "A linear time algorithm for the 1-fixed-endpoint path cover problem on interval graphs",
        "Lower bounds based on the exponential time hypothesis",
        "An optimal algorithm for the kùëòk-fixed-endpoint path cover on proper interval graphs",
        "Linear algorithms to recognize outerplanar and maximal outerplanar graphs",
        "Approximation algorithms for the maximum hamiltonian path problem with specified endpoint(s)",
        "Cyclically ordered sets",
        "A survey on pickup and delivery problems. Part I: Transportation between customers and depot",
        "A survey on pickup and delivery problems. Part II: Transportation between pickup and delivery locations",
        "A dynamic programming solution to the single vehicle many-to-many immediate request dial-a-ride problem",
        "Graph searches and their end vertices",
        "A polynomial-time algorithm for MCS partial search order on chordal graphs",
        "Linearizing partial search orders",
        "Ready to Order? On Vertex and Edge Orderings of Graphs",
        "Characterizations of outerplanar graphs",
        "Reducing path TSP to TSP",
        "The path-partition problem in bipartite distance-hereditary graphs"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 57 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Computing Hamiltonian Paths with Partial Order Restrictions, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
